The application of either organic or inorganic fertilizer is done to supplement what the soil could not provide for better crop productivity. A recommended fertilizer rate per hectare or per hill is followed to avoid adverse effects on the plant and soil.

 

Application of Organic and Inorganic Fertilizers

The following is recommended for the application of organic and inorganic fertilizer: 

  1. Prior to the application of plastic mulch, apply two tons of organic fertilizer for a hectare or 200 kg for 1000 m2; 

  2. As basal, apply 15 g/hill of complete fertilizer;

  3. During dry season, apply 10-15 g/hill urea and muriate of potash once a month;

  4. During wet season, side dress 10-15 g/hill urea and muriate of potash every two weeks; 

  5. Apply the same amount of fertilizer material per hill as needed;

  6. Spray fermented fruit/plant juice (FFJ/FPJ) at 15, 45 and 60 days after transplanting or up to fruiting stage.  Formulate 1:5 ratio of FFJ/FPJ and water, respectively. Use fish amino acid, seaweed extracts and other organic plant supplements.

 

Preparation and Application of Gibberellic Acid

A gram of GA3 tablet is pulverized and dissolved in 5-10 ml of ethyl alcohol. Pulverized tablet is mixed in a liter of distilled water to produce 1,000 ppm of GA3 stock solution. GA3 can be sprayed three times (30, 60 and 90 DAS) and done early in the morning. The formula below is used to come up with 25 ppm GA3:

                                C1 V1 = C2 V2

                 1,000 ppm (?) = (25ppm) (2,000 ml)

                                         =50,000 ppm ml

                                            1,000 ppm

                                   V1 = 50 ml

                              Water = 1,950 ml

In water management, the following should be done: 

  • Irrigate in between pair rows weekly during crop establishment and bi-weekly at flowering and fruit setting. 

  • During dry season, irrigate at 14 days after emergence (DAE) and repeat every seven days throughout the growing period. 

  • Water/irrigate the crops twice a week for faster shoot development and minimize the bitter taste of shoot and fruits. 

  • Do not irrigate too much to avoid the incidence of fruit rot and root rot.
